FacilityName: Cedar City Regional Wastewater Treatment Facility

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Cedar City Regional Wastewater Treatment Facility (CCRWWTF) is owned and operated by Cedar City and treats wastewater from Cedar City, Enoch City and the surrounding county area. The CCRWWTF is located eight miles northwest of Cedar City in Iron County, Utah.  The North American Industrial Classification System code for the wastewater treatment facilities is 221320, Sewage Treatment Facilities.  CCRWWTF operates in accordance with all applicable federal, state and local environmental and health and safety regulations and is committed to maintaining compliance with these regulations.  The CCRWWTF has implemented an Emergency Action Plan at the facility in coordination with local emergency response agencies.

The plant treats approximately 2.4 million gallons of wastewater per day (mgd) with a capacity of 4.4 mgd. The plant uses chlorine as secondary treatment to disinfect wastewater. Effluent from the plant is land applied to a 2,400 acre site located next to the treatment facility. Because effluent from the plant is land applied, the system does not require a dechlorination process. The amount of chlorine used in the chlorination processes exceed the threshold quantities (TQ) as defined by the U.S. Environmental Protections Agency's Risk Management Programs (RMP) and Occupational Safety and Health Administration's Process Safety Management (PSM) regulations. PSM regulations define the TQ for chlorine as 1,500 pounds, and RMP regulations define the TQ for chlorine 2,500 pounds.

The RMP/PSM regulations require proactive identification, evaluation and mitigation or prevention of chemical releases that could occur because of failures in processes, procedures, or equipment. nts and mitigation measures identified in the PHA that CCRWWTF has committed to accomplish have been completed or are in progress.  Any other measures identified by employees, during workplace hazard surveys or because of audit activities, will be thoroughly reviewed and considered for implementation.

At the time of this report, CCRWWTF has updated their program to comply with the RMP/PSM requirements.  CCRWWTF is committed to reviewing and updating the program periodically, as appropriate, and maintaining compliance with regulatory requirements.  This RMP/PSM plan complies with all applicable regulations, and is accessible to all interested employees and contractors, at all times.  CCRWWTF has been proactive in developing and implementing the RMP/PSM for the treatment plant, not only to comply with state and federal requirements, but also as a commitment to workplace and public safety as a top priority.
